photo.title: Monastery of Alcobaça

photo.description: alcobaça monastery :beautiful gothic monument in portugal (unesco) монастырь Собор Katedra :The most significant Cistercian foundation in Portugal, the Monastery of Alcobaça dates from 1153, resulting from a donation made by Dom Afonso Henriques to St. Bernard of Clairvaux. It was one of the most powerful abbeys of the Cistercian order. The medieval monastic buildings are still preserved almost entirely, as are the 14th-century Gothic tombs of Dom Pedro and Dona Inês de Castro. The main feature of the city is essentially the Monastery that proudly presents a long and sombre façade with 18th Century embellishments. This austerity is further emphasized in the cloisters with its apt name of "Cloister of Silence". In contrast within the Abbey is the massive kitchen with a running stream specially diverted to pass through as a supply of fresh water. The open area of the kitchen chimney is large enough to take a whole ox for roasting. The surround to the sacristy doorway is an outstanding example of Manueline decoration. In 1794, Lord Beckford visited the Abbey and commented that he found some 300 monks "living in a very splendid manner"!
photo.tags: architecture travel vacation alcobaça mosteiro monument portugal church kerk iglesia europe city gothik gothic beautiful belesa abbey unesco ilustrarportugal see katedraal monastery собор монастырь katedra catholic cathedral

photo.description: The fountain in front of the refectory entrance was meant for the monks to clean themselves before meals—or so we’re told. With such a beautiful and impractical design, though, I’m inclined to believe their cleanliness was a symbol for the spirit. Mosteiro de Alcobaça / Alcobaça Monastery.

photo.description: In March 1147, facing the Moors in an important battle at Santarém, Afonso Henríques vowed that he would build a great monastery if God granted him victory. After winning the battle and becoming the first Portuguese king, Afonso kept his promise. He founded the Monastery of St. Mary at Alçobaca in 1153 and gave it to Bernard of Clairvaux, a Cistercian abbot who had strongly promoted the Crusades.
photo.tags: alcobaça monastery
photo.title: Alcobaça Monastery

photo.description: Alcobaça, Portugal (2008). A fachada do Mosteiro. Neste site, existe uma série de espectaculares vistas a 360º das principais salas do Mosteiro de Alcobaça. A não perder! ----- The Monastery's facade. On this site, you can find a series of spectacular 360º views of the Alcobaça Monastery's main rooms. Not to be missed!

photo.description: This is Portugal's largest monastery and one of the greatest historical mysteries from my trip. We're talking about 12th century construction in immaculate condition; as if built yesterday. With what seems like most places just falling apart, this stands 900 years later with more splendour than ever.

photo.title: reflections on faith

photo.description: The west façade of the monastery church is the majestic Cistercian Gothic style with later Baroque embellishments. The portal and rose window are part of the original Gothic church (1178-1252), while the statues and two flanking towers were added in the beginning of the 18th century by architect João Turriano. The long wings attached to the church on either side are also Baroque additions. In the back of the church is a Gothic apse with eight flying buttresses.
photo.title: Alcobaça Monastery

photo.description: Founded by the first Portuguese king in 1153, the Cistercian Alcobaça Monastery (Portuguese: Mosteiro de Santa Maria de Alcobaça) was one of the richest and most prestigious monasteries in medieval Europe. Its church was the first building in Portugal to adopt the Gothic style and was (and still is!) the largest church in the country.
photo.title: Alcobaça Monastery

photo.title: Churches 07-06-09 M(4)

photo.description: Long story short, she was the beloved wife of Prince (then King) Pedro I (Peter I) of Portugal. She was Castilian, and Pedro’s father Afonso began to fear that after his own death, the kingdom would fall into the hands of Inês’ Castilian family. He had her killed by prominent Portuguese nobles. Once Pedro I was king and learned about why and by whom Inês had been killed, he sought justice. The three assassins were hunted down and Pedro—the legend has it—ripped out their hearts with his bare hands. In order to teach his court some respect, he then exhumed his wife’s body (now around 2 years old), dressed her up and put her on the throne. All courtesans were then ‘kindly asked’ to pay homage to the Queen by kissing her hand. Her body was finally put to rest in this sarcophagus in the Alcobaça church. The sarcophagus has four figures of monks for feet—both Pedro’s and Inês’ bodies were buried in the monastery, where monks were supposed to closely guard them. Mosteiro de Alcobaça / Alcobaça Monastery.
photo.tags: alcobaça angel church portugal portugal2009 religion sculpture stone tomb alcobaça leiria
photo.title: Sarcophagus of Inês de Castro

photo.description: The arcs inside Alcobaça Monastery trying to reach for the skies. The church and monastery were the first Gothic buildings in Portugal. Due to its artistic and historical importance, it was listed by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site in 1989. This is also the burial place of king Peter I of Portugal and his mistress Inês de Castro, one of the most tragic love stories from Portugal history.
photo.tags: alcobaça portugal alcobaçamonastery mosteirodealcobaça arcs arcos
